awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope for Research and Teaching in the Fields of Chemistry, Geology, Biology, Physics, and Forensic Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Programs as well as the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).  Professor Rosalynn Quinones-Fernandez from Marshall University and colleagues Michael Norton, Aley El-Shazly, Iyad Hijazi and Sean McBride have acquired a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM).  A scanning electron microscope is an essential tool for the study of materials.  It focuses a beam of electrons at the sample.  The electrons interact and are scattered from the material to produce an image of the surface and its structure.  A field-emission SEM has a electron gun designed to provide very high resolution images.  This instrument upgrade improves image resolution and allow elemental analysis presently unavailable to researchers at Marshall.  The science enabled by the acquisition impacts areas of interest to the community (for example, Appalachian geology, insects endemic to West Virginia and forensic/environmental analyses).  Undergraduate research training and course instruction (100 students/year) involves largely regional students from Appalachia. The FESEM enhances at least five different annual outreach activities some of which target specifically minority and underrepresented students.  A researcher from West Virginia State University, a Historically Black College and University, and another researcher at the University of Charleston also benefit. 

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels.  Research projects are ongoing to control surface properties of metal oxide nanoparticles and to investigate DNA based platforms for single molecule sensing nanostructures.  Other projects focus on atomistic modeling techniques to probe for nanomaterial with unique properties, and experiments on self-assembled nanoparticle membranes. Investigations are underway to model and simulate rigid and flexible body dynamics for soft robotic applications. Other investigations use geological sample imaging and analysis to understand the tectonic setting of metamorphic and igneous rocks of the southern Appalachians. Arachnid sensory morphology and characterization of sensory sensillae in the Tsetse fly are being studied.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The jsm7200flv field emission Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) and associated Oxford X-ray analysis instrument was acquired by Marshall University (MU) with the National Science Foundation (NSF) Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award #1828358 and installed in and operational mid July 2019.  The machine was intended to replace and upgrade function of our jsm5310lv SEM that has been in service at MU since 1998.  Prior to this installation, a thorough room survey was completed to ensure that mechanical and electrical disturbances would not affect function of the SEM. The SEM room needed major renovations including partitioning the room and adding modern furnishings. The SEM instrument in this environment has its own dedicated space including sample preparation facilities.   

In the first 9 months of operation, 339 hours were logged by users on the SEM from the departments of Chemistry, Physics, Geology, and engineering.  From dates staring 3/22/2020, Covid-19 caused MU campus lock down, so from 3/22/2019 through 6/12/2020 - no outside users were allowed to complete work with the SEM, only periodic checks on machine status were performed.   Between June 2020 and July 2021, an additional 331 hours were logged on the SEM.  Some major users of the instrument post covid lockdown were from MU chemistry, forensic science, physics, geology, biology, school of medicine, and engineering departments.  Also, outside collaborations from Shawnee State University Geology Department, WVU Wood Sciences and Chemical Engineering, Rubberlite corp., Parabon Nanolabs, and BHE corp. used the instrument.  Additionally, local high school students toured the facilities and were given demos (including virtual ones) of the SEM.  During summers, young rising MU freshman students of First2 program (first generation college students) were able to have some hands-on experience with the instrument. The instrument was showcased for the West Virginia Science Olympiads, High School Physics Days, Appalachian section American Association of Physics Teacher fall meetings, and the WV Governor's STEM Institute.   One manager/technician, 2 local WV residents, 4 industry customers, 11 graduate students, 19 PhD researchers, 50-60 undergraduate students including 5-7 proficient users, and quite literally hundreds of high school students via demonstrations have used the SEM. The instrument was used evenly between research and student training/courses such as Engineering Materials Lab, analytical chemistry, and forensic science analysis. For example, the SEM was used to analyze particle size and elemental composition of various types of fingerprint powders and compared them with certified fingerprint examiners for quality of pristine and diminish prints. This project was published by Quinones group at the Forensic Chemistry journal.

The instrument was used for preliminary studies used to inform a proposal to the NSF for RII Track-1: Structural and Functional Connectomics: Innovations in Neuroscience through Advanced Data Science, which will involve combined electron microscopy and optical (fluorescence) microscopy. Use of the microscope by an undergraduate researcher, supported through an NSF infrastructure grant to characterize gold nanoparticles produced using nanosphere lithography, helped inform MU in the writing of the recently awarded NSF major instrumentation grant: Acquisition of a CytoViva system for multidisciplinary research and education in nanotechnology. Furthermore, 2 publications related to nanoparticle integration into silk fibers were supported by imaging experiments performed with the microscope.

The instrument was also used for quantitative analysis of minerals from schists and gneisses from the Little Pine Garnet Mine (Blue Ridge Province, Appalachian Mountains). These results will be used to constrain the pressure and temperature conditions of metamorphism of the area, in an attempt to understand its tectonic evolution. A lot of the work carried out by El-Shazly and his student assistants was aimed at optimizing the analytical procedures to obtain accurate and precise results.

In summary, the addition of the JEOL 7200flv field emission SEM with associated Oxford X-ray analysis equipment has undoubtably increased and enhanced Marshall University?s research capabilities for both faculty and students. Overall, in scholarly activities where the SEM was used for imaging particles or analysis, there have been 5 workshops (in-person and virtual) hosted using the SEM, 6 papers published with 2 in preparation, 3 local,  7 state/regional, and 1 national presentations by students and Principal Investigators with 3 more anticipated in the remaining 2021-22 academic year, $48,000 dollars in stipends from external awards for undergraduate/graduate students to work on projects that relied on the imaging capabilities/analysis of the SEM, and nearly $3,000,000 in external funding from state and federal agencies has been applied for in the form of small or large scale multi-institutional proposals where students would to some extent be exposed to aspects of the new SEM capabilities. In addition, the new SEM was utilized in Marshall University undergraduate labs where students were able to observe the operation stages of an SEM and look at various material samples.

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2021
Modified by: Rosalynn Quinones-Fernandez

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1. Representatives of Rubberlite Inc. of Huntington brought specialty urethane foam materials to our lab so we could characterize the cells that provide resilience to the product.
    David Neff
    Creative Commons
    Rosalynn Quinones-Fernandez
    Rubberlite
  • Figure 2. Elkins, WV residents Phil Reed and Amy Butcher came to our facility with their young son to investigate a curious metallic object that they found in the Elkins area. They suspected that there may be some gold in the agglomerated chunk of metallic rock. We see that copper is present in lar
    David Neff
    Creative Commons
    Rosalynn Quinones-Fernandez
    Elkins
  • igure 3. David Haas from U. of Charleston visited a couple times with an enthusiastic undergraduate student Desma Feather. The visits prompted Ms. Feather to write up an abstract for our spring research day at MU. That research day was cancelled due to Covid-19.
    Des Feather
    Creative Commons
    Rosalynn Quinones-Fernandez
    UC-student work
  • Figure 4. We were able to entertain hundreds of local high school students (one small group at a time) during our annual High School Physics Day event sponsored by the MU physics dept. (Dr. Sean McBride). Thankfully, our new SEM lab is spacious enough to accommodate 10 or more students at a time.
    David Neff
    Public Domain
    Rosalynn Quinones-Fernandez
    Physics day-butterfly's wing
  • Figure 5. This is an example of a compression fitting ferrule from a customer who was concerned with finding out which ferrule vendor made product with lowest roughness and most consistent composition.
    David Neff
    Public Domain
    Rosalynn Quinones-Fernandez
    ferrule
  • Figure 6. Zoning in the mineral zircon revealed by cathodoluminescence imaging. X-ray mapping of the same crystal reveals that the zoning is caused by substitution of niobium and yttrium for zirconium.
    Dr. AleyEl-Shazly
    Creative Commons
    Rosalynn Quinones-Fernandez
    Geology
